content.question: Figure 1 shows a block that slides up a rough incline, momentarily comes to rest near the top of the incline, and then slides back down the incline. Figure 2 shows a free-body diagram for the block as it moves up the incline, where <math alttext="N" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the normal force, <math alttext="lowercase f" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the force of friction, and <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the force of Earth’s gravity. Figure 3 shows a free-body diagram for the block as it moves down the incline. Based on these figures, which of the following is a correct statement?

choices.label: Since friction changes direction as the block’s motion changes direction, friction is a conservative force.
Since friction is always against the motion of the block, the total work done by friction is zero.
Since the normal force is always perpendicular to the motion, the normal force is a conservative force.
Since a component of gravity is always directed toward the original position of the block, gravity is a conservative force.
Since gravity is with the motion of the block up the incline and also with the motion of the block down the incline, gravity is a nonconservative force.

content.answer: Since a component of gravity is always directed toward the original position of the block, gravity is a conservative force.
